title: Head of a Kushite Ruler
description:
Head of a king in unidentified green stone, originally furnished with back pillar. Full, almost square face with eyes and brows originally inlaid, bull neck. Skin areas polished scalp area dull and covered with close fitting ‘cap’ with small, rounded flaps near ears; uraeus with wide curve. 
Condition: Inlays lost, right eyelid chipped. Ears slightly chipped. Headdress apparently has been hammered though possibly it was covered with metal fitting in antiquity.
section: The Third Intermediate Period and the Beginning of the Late Peri

museum_location.name: 19th Dynasty to Roman Period, Martha A. and Robert S. Rubin Gallery, 3rd Floor

completeness.name: Best
completeness.description: All data has been vetted. Objects generally have quality photos and descriptions.

labels.content: Kushite royal statues, particularly examples from Upper Egypt, emphasize the foreign, non-Egyptian origin of their subjects. This head, perhaps of King Shabaqa, shows the ruler with a broad, nearly round face characteristic of the Kushite people. His regalia also reflects Kushite influence, and his shortly cropped hair—bound by a broad headband—is a feature never seen on native Egyptian sculpture. A knob, now gone, at the front of the headband once accommodated two uraeus cobras. On statues of kings, the double cobra is uniquely Kushite as well.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art

exhibitions.title: Africa in Antiquity: The Arts of Ancient Nubia and the Sudan
